item.title: Hillary add a quote by W.C. Fields
item.description: "I am free of all prejudice. I hate everyone equally. " -- W.C. Fields

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I do not want people to be very agreeable, as it saves me the trouble of liking them a great deal." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Some time ago," he said, "--how long it seems! -- I remember saying to a young friend of mine of the name of Spiller, 'Comrade Spiller, never confuse the unusual with the impossible.' It is my guiding rule in life." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "I am Psmith," said the old Etonian reverently. "There is a preliminary P before the name. This, however, is silent. Like the tomb. Compare such words as ptarmigan, psalm, and phthisis." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Another of these strong silent men. The world is full of us." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Dorothy Sayers
item.description: "A facility for quotation covers the absence of original thought." -- Dorothy Sayers

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Dorothy L. Sayers
item.description: "Nothing goes so well with a hot fire and buttered crumpets as a wet day without and a good dose of comfortable horrors within. The heavier the lashing of the rain and the ghastlier the details, the better the flavour seems to be." -- Dorothy L. Sayers

item.title: Hillary add a quote by John Greenleaf Whittier
item.description: "Of all sad words of tongue or pen, the saddest are these, 'It might have been." -- John Greenleaf Whittier

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Red hair, sir, in my opinion, is dangerous." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "The voice of Love seemed to call to me, but it was a wrong number." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "At the age of eleven or thereabouts women acquire a poise and an ability to handle difficult situations which a man, if he is lucky, manages to achieve somewhere in the later seventies." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "In a series of events, all of which had been a bit thick, this, in his opinion, achieved the maximum of thickness." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "I could see that, if not actually disgruntled, he was far from being gruntled." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "I suppose he must have taken about a nine or something in hats. Shows what a rotten thing it is to let your brain develop too much." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Freddie experienced the sort of abysmal soul-sadness which afflicts one of Tolstoy's Russian peasants when, after putting in a heavy day's work strangling his father, beating his wife, and dropping the baby into the city's reservoir, he turns to the cupboards, only to find the vodka bottle empty." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Warm-hearted! I should think he has to wear asbestos vests!" -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Providence looks after all the chumps of this world, and personally, I'm all for it." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "I hadn't the heart to touch my breakfast. I told Jeeves to drink it himself." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "A man who has spent most of his adult life trying out a series of patent medicines is always an optimist." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "Mike nodded. A sombre nod. The nod Napoleon might have given if somebody had met him in 1812 and said, "So, you're back from Moscow, eh?" -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "A man's subconscious self is not the ideal companion. It lurks for the greater part of his life in some dark den of its own, hidden away, and emerges only to taunt and deride and increase the misery of a miserable hour." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "If he had a mind, there was something on it." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "There's too much of that where-every-prospect-pleases-and-only-man-is-vile stuff buzzing around for my taste." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by P.G. Wodehouse
item.description: "...it has been well said that it is precisely these moments when we are feeling that ours is the world and everything that's in it that Fate selects for sneaking up on us with the rock in the stocking." -- P.G. Wodehouse

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Marcus Tullius Cicero
item.description: "A room without books is like a body without a soul." -- Marcus Tullius Cicero

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Groucho Marx
item.description: "Outside of a dog, a book is man's best friend. Inside of a dog it's too dark to read." -- Groucho Marx

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "The person, be it gentleman or lady, who has not pleasure in a good novel, must be intolerably stupid." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "I declare after all there is no enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of any thing than of a book! -- When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not an excellent library." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Ah! There is nothing like staying at home, for real comfort." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Hillary add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "If one cannot enjoy reading a book over and over again, there is no use in reading it at all." -- Oscar Wilde
